subject: Signed Books at the JCC
event: The illustrated anniversary hardcover edition of A GAME OF THRONES is scheduled for release on October 18. They will be available across the nation from your favorite local bookstore or online bookseller. We also expect to have a couple hundred for sale the Jean Cocteau Cinema Bookstore, and available by mail order. And those will be signed (my manager twisted my arm). ((Sorry, no personalizations or inscriptions, just straight signatures)). To preorder, go to http://www.jeancocteaubooks.com/bookstore/a-game-of-thrones-the-illustrated-edition-pre-order/?ct=t(061220156_12_2015)&mc_cid=5a7419c5bb&mc_eid=78a442bf0c We also have on hand RIGHT NOW some autographed hardcovers of the latest Wild Cards book for Tor, HIGH STAKES. These are signed by yours truly, and by John J. Miller, one of the writers. Of course, ALL the books sold by the JCC are autographed by the authors, so we also have many other titles available signed. Here are a few of them: To check out the full list, go to http://www.jeancocteaubooks.com/ And happy reading.

props.taglist: jean cocteau cinema bookstore, wild cards, game of thrones

comments.article:
Definitely my favourite online bookseller!
Already placed my second international order, including the anniversary GoT, and keep recommending JCC to my friends. Even though shipping isn't cheap, it balances out considering the price of books in general in Norway.

Saw in your previous post that you were planning to release an enhanced iBook edition of A GAME OF THRONES. I was curious whether you would follow suit to release illustrated editions of each book in the series in the future? Have really enjoyed Gary Gianni's illustrations for A KNIGHT OF THE SEVEN KINGDOMS, and I'd love to see what Mr. Gianni, Magali Villenueve, Marc Simonetti, Marc Fishman and others can do with iconic scenes like Blackwater, the Red Wedding, the Blackfish and Jaime at Riverrun or Daznak's Pit. (Some of them have done artwork on these scenes already, but it'd be lovely to have this incorporated into future editions)
comments.subject: Illustrated Editions of Each Book

comments.article: If the anniversary edition of A GAME OF THRONES does well, Bantam will probably follow with anniversary editions of A CLASH OF KINGS (in 2019) and A STORM OF SWORDS (in 2020).  Suitably illustrated.
comments.subject: Re: Illustrated Editions of Each Book

comments.subject: Magic One

Hey George,

Have you seen Stranger Things?
comments.subject: `Stranger Things

comments.article:
I've always wondered how successful authors sign so many books! Signing them has to be the most monotonous thing in the world!

I participated in an audio study during college in which I used earphones to listen to the voices of four people repeating the same lines over and over (and I used a computer/mouse to rate each line for clarity). I did this for more than eight hours over two days. Some participants fell asleep. Others got up after a couple of hours and left without getting paid.

I imagine that signing books has to be just as tedious and boring. Of course, we certainly appreciate it! We buy the signed books, place them on our shelves, show them off to friends and family and plan on leaving them to loved ones.

So, thank you for the sacrifice! I hope that you're watching football or listening to something wonderful to help pass that time!
comments.subject: I'll be ordering one!

comments.article: "Mongrels" is so so so fucking great. Stephen Graham Jones was my Clarion West instructor and he was terrifying and amazing.

Just a reminder to people who aren't "in the know":  GRRM still does book signings, although rarely, so if you're one of those quirky people (like me) who wants to watch the author actually sign the book, you can still get a book (usually only one) signed at a con signing.  Neil Gaiman, on the other hand, does few (if any) signings anymore, so that's something to think about.  When his next book, Norse Mythology, comes out early next year, I expect that the JCC will be the only place (if there are any) that has signed copies.
comments.subject: Neil Gaiman stuff

comments.article: Actually, we can't be sure we will have signed copies of NORSE MYTHOLOGY... that all depends on when (and if) Neil next visits Santa Fe again.   He's a travelin' man, y'know.
comments.subject: Re: Neil Gaiman stuff

comments.article:
Hello, George.
Do you have a routine for writing? Or you write then when inspiration comes ?

I'm start writing short novels, but i can't do with routines, what you do to get inspiration ?

Thanks.
comments.subject: Routine

comments.article:
Very nice visuals ;) And by the way first time I ever come on your "Not a Blog", it looks pretty interesting and quite simple at the same time.

Oh and, thanks to your writings and everything, I discovered Scott Lynch's work, so thank you for making me know him (I already knew Joe Abercrombie and others). In the meantime, I wonder : would you recommand to young writers to publish their books, in the first place, in United States or in England ?

Congratulations for keeping writing - answering - AND everything ! Can't wait to have the last Game of Thrones books editions :)
comments.subject: Actually

comments.article: Excellent.  Just pre ordered my copy of the 20th anniversary edition of A Game of Thrones. Really looking forward to re reading it and looking at the new illustrations.

Hi George, big fan here. In Iran your books are being translated and monetized both in internet (mostly uncensored version) or in print (censored version). I wanted to know your stand on this issue, because at the moment Iran is not among the countries obeying the copy right law, but you have huge fan base there. Is there any plans to release an official Persian translations of your books in the future?
comments.subject: Persian translation of your books

comments.article:
We've had a few inquiries from publishers in Iran, which I have forwarded to my foreign rights agent for follow up. However, I do not believe that any of them has resulted in a deal yet.

I am hopeful that we will have something in the future.
comments.subject: Re: Persian translation of your books
Re: Persian translation of your books

comments.article: Talking about books, what was your inspiration for "writing" the Seven Pointed Star? I picture it like something between I-ching and The Bible, hope you actually write it one fine day as a reference book, kind of like The World of Ice & Fire.

To keep this message on-subject, I'll start by saying I'm looking forward to a similar release for A Feast for Crows.

In that book, you wrote about Brienne standing in Lord Tarly's tent as he blamed her for any potential sexual assault that might befall her. In the past few days, I've been more shocked than I ought to be to see that people still agree with that argument. If you had been in that tent or any other room where that argument is being made, what would you say?

I'm currently doing a reread of the series, but this time in audio (currently on CoK), and I've noticed quite a few names/places are pronounced different than in the show. Do you have a preferred pronunciation? I suppose it doesn't really matter, I'm just curious.

Thanks!
comments.subject: Since you brought up Game of Thrones..

comments.article: You say poTAYto, I say PaTATo, let's call the whole thing off.  :)
comments.subject: Re: Since you brought up Game of Thrones..

comments.article:
Why wouldn't it ship worldwide? You have fans outside America, you know.Thankfully, a friend was able to order it for me^^
Keep up the good work! I'm patiently waiting for the Winds of Winter!

Hi George,

I've been wondering - In ASOIAF (As opposed to Game of Thrones) what is the climate like around the area of Castle Black? During the peak of summer, could you techically get away with shorts & a T-shirt once in a while, or is it always cold with snow cover that never really melts? On the show, they made it seem like the latter is true.
comments.subject: Question about climate at The Wall

comments.article:
All the art in this book looks gorgeous. It's clear the artists put in a lot of effort making Westeros and the characters come to life. After looking at the previews up on various sites, I already know chapter 10's art will be hard to beat as my favorite :) Do you have a personal favorite as well?

Just curious, I know that only a few select pieces will be published in color, but is there a chance that one day we'll see the other new pieces in color as well instead of just in greyscale? Or is that off the table?
Totally unrelated but I've heard rumors that you might be cancelling the winds of winter!! üò≠üò≠ make us wait another 5 years but don't cancel it please üò≠üò≠
I have no idea who makes up these moronic stories... but as I have said a thousand times, if you did not read it here, don't believe a word of it.
I have been enjoying that one very much, I must say. I've just come across sound snippets, exciting!
comments.subject: Is this the same as the recent Apple illustrated enhanced edition of TGoT?

comments.subject: Original Limited Edition of A Game of Thrones on eBay

comments.article:
When AGOT was first published, the first sentence of the back cover text was: "Long ago, in a time forgotten, a preternatural event threw the seasons out of balance."

At first I thought that maybe someone else wrote the cover text, because there's nothing like this in the books and the sentence is missing for some of the later editions. But then I found the book description on your website actually includes it, so there can't be too much wrong with it, can it?

Can you comment on this in any way? Was the cover text written by you or by someone else? Were you involved in the decision whether to use the first sentence or not?
comments.subject: Back Cover Text
